text.0: drink of the juice o indra at thy plea sure for thy first draught is early morns libation.
text.1: rejoice that thou mayst slay our foes o hero and we with lauds will tell thy mighty exploits.
text.2: thou hast a car more swift than thought o indra thercon come hither come to drink the soma.
text.3: let thy bay steeds thy stallions hasten hither with whom thou cornest nigh and art delighted.
text.4: deck out thy body with the fairest colours with golden splendour of the sun adorn it.
text.5: o indra turn thee hitherward invited by us thy friends be seated and be joyful.
text.6: o thou whose grandeur in thy festive transports not even these two great worlds have comprehended.
text.7: come indra with thy dear bay horses harnessed come to our dwelling and the food thou lovest.
text.8: pressed for thy joyous banquet is the soma soma whereof thou indra ever drinking.
text.9: hast waged unequalled battles with thy foemen which prompts the mighty flow of thine abundance.
text.10: found from of old is this thy cup o indra Śatakratu drink therefrom the soma.
text.11: filled is the beaker with the meath that gladdens the beaker which all deities delight in.
text.12: from many a side with proffered entertainment the folk are calling thee o mighty indra.
text.13: these our libations shall for thee be richest in sweet meath dvink thereof and find them pleasant.
text.14: i will declare thy deeds of old o indra the mighty acts which thou hast first accomplished.
text.15: in genuine wrath thou loosenedst the mountain so that the brahman easily found the cattle.
text.16: lord of the hosts amid our bands be seated they call thee greatest sage among the sages.
text.17: nothing is done even far away without thee great wondrous maghavan is the hymn i sing thee.
text.18: aim of our eyes be thou for we implore thee o maghavan friend of friends and lord of treasures.
text.19: fight warrior strong in truth fight thou the battle give us our share of undivided riches.
